caseTitle: CHARITY AGYEIWAH v E.M.S., P&T CORPORATI ON
summary: In this 2008 Supreme Court of Ghana case, Charity Agyeiwah appealed against E.M.S., P&T Corporation regarding a lost parcel containing £10,000 worth of travellers' cheques sent to the UK. The trial court ruled in her favor, but the Court of Appeal reversed the decision, citing lack of jurisdiction by the trial judge to declare a statutory provision unconstitutional and questioning the evidence. The Supreme Court found that the Court of Appeal erred in dismissing the factual basis of the claim, particularly given corroboration by the defendant's own witness (DW1) who confirmed receipt of the travellers' cheques. However, the Court held that the constitutional issue—whether Section 43(1) of NRCD 311 was inconsistent with Article 18(2) of the 1992 Constitution—was irrelevant because the contract predated the Constitution’s enforcement and thus could not be applied retroactively. The appeal was allowed on factual grounds, emphasizing that the appellate court should have referred the constitutional question to the Supreme Court under Article 130(2) if deemed material.
citations: Barclays Bank Ghana Ltd. v Sakari [1996-1997] SCGLR639
rationaleHighlights: The defendant's own witness (DW1) corroborated that the parcel contained £10,000 in travellers' cheques, supporting the appellant's claim.
The Court of Appeal misdirected itself by rejecting this corroborated evidence without compelling reason.
The trial judge lacked jurisdiction to rule on the constitutionality of NRCD 311, but the appellate court failed in its duty under Article 130(2) to refer the issue to the Supreme Court.
The 1992 Constitution cannot apply retroactively to a contract formed before its effective date.
In civil cases, proof on balance of probabilities suffices, and the evidence met this standard.
The constitutional question was ultimately deemed irrelevant to the resolution of the contractual dispute.
Appellate courts must refer constitutional issues to the Supreme Court when they arise in lower courts.
The appeal succeeded primarily on factual grounds, not constitutional ones.
